title: Religious Pilgrimage: China and Tibet
xlist: Same As: REL 986, section 01
description: This course comprises comparative study of historic and contemporary religious pilgrimage rituals among Tibetan Buddhist and Roman Catholic communities in China, including visual and textual representation as well as theological meaning. The course begins with lectures on Tibetan Buddhist and Chinese Catholic ritual practices surrounding religious pilgrimage, including natural and built sacred sites, their textual and visual representations, and theological interpretations. In early May the class travels to Shanghai and Lhasa (May 9—18), visiting Sheshan, Lhasa Jokhang (epicenter of Tibetan Buddhist pilgrimage), and the Potala Palace (winter residence of the Dalai Lamas), as well as sacred sites outside Lhasa. Students study ritual, visual, and material depictions of the rituals that occur at those sites, with lectures in situ. Travel and accommodation costs are covered by the Institute of Sacred Music; students must purchase a visa for China, any medical immunizations needed, and meals. Prerequisite: applicants from Yale College and the graduate and professional schools are welcome; interested students should send a short statement (500–800 words) by December 15 to kristen.forman@yale.edu explaining why they wish to take the course, how it fits with their academic interests and pursuits, and noting any relevant prior experience. Applicants will be notified before the start of the term. All participants must have a current passport, valid through November 18, 2018, with at least two blank pages.
